Issues.Title: fix(router): adjust UrlTree redirect to replace URL if in eager update
Issues.Body:
Resubmit #31168 now that google3 tests can pass. This requires http://cl/272696717 to be patched.
Original description from jasonaden:

Without this change when using UrlTree redirects in urlUpdateStrategy="eager", the URL would get
updated to the target location, then redirected. This resulted in having an additional entry in the
history and thus the back button would be broken (going back would land on the URL causing a new
redirect).

Additionally, there was a bug where the redirect, even without urlUpdateStrategy="eager", could
create a history with too many entries. This was due to kicking off a new navigation within the
navigation cancelling logic. With this PR the new navigation is pushed to the next tick with a
setTimeout, allowing the page being redirected from to be cancelled before starting a new
navigation.

Related to #27148

- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
If a CanActivate guard returns a UrlTree, the router performs a redirect. Currently both the source and target of the redirect will exist in the browser history. So if the user hits the back button they will go back to the source of the redirect which will then redirect back to the page they were already on.

Issue Number: #27148


## What is the new behavior?
When a CanActivate guard returns a UrlTree, triggering a redirect, there will only be a single history entry containing the destination of the redirect. Hitting the back button will take the user to the previous page.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): allow abstract directives to have an invalid constructor
Issues.Body:
For abstract directives, i.e. directives without a selector, it may
happen that their constructor is called explicitly from a subclass,
hence its parameters are not required to be valid for Angular's DI
purposes. Prior to this commit however, having an abstract directive
with a constructor that has parameters that are not eligible for
Angular's DI would produce a compilation error.

A similar scenario may occur for `@Injectable`s, where an explicit
`use*` definition allows for the constructor to be irrelevant. For
example, the situation where `useFactory` is specified allows for the
constructor to be called explicitly with any value, so its constructor
parameters are not required to be valid. For `@Injectable`s this is
handled by generating a DI factory function that throws.

This commit implements the same solution for abstract directives, such
that a compilation error is avoided while still producing an error at
runtime if the type is instantiated implicitly by Angular's DI
mechanism.

Fixes #32981

Issues.Title: ivy doesn't handle style value 0 (zero) correctly
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
`@angular/core`


### Is this a regression?

Yes. Works in `~9.0.0-next.9` with Ivy disabled but does not work with Ivy enabled.


### Description

`[style.property]` treats `0` as `'0'` in non-Ivy Angular but as falsy in Ivy which in turn removes the attribute. Since it could be a computed value (`[style.opacity]="1 - somevar"`) it's probably best to treat `0` as an actual value.


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

Without Ivy:
- `[style.opacity]="0"` -> applied correctly (`opacity: 0`)
- `[style.opacity]="'0'"` -> applied correctly (`opacity: 0`)

With Ivy:
- `[style.opacity]="0"` -> not applied (no `opacity` set)
- `[style.opacity]="'0'"` -> applied correctly (`opacity: 0`)

https://angular.io/guide/deployment#opting-out-of-differential-loading

### Description
We have made changes to the "standard" Angular project config (tsconfig.json -> tsconfig.app.json for example) throughout the evolution of the CLI. Due to the power of `angular.json`, old projects keep working, but don't look like newer projects.

2. Add to each item, a directive that has a `@HostListener` for `'dragenter'` and `'dragleave'` events.
3. Drag the items around, the host listeners do not fire when one item is dragged over another.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
Native drag events should fire.


#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
Native drag events do not fire.


#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.8
- CDK/Material: 8.2.2
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows

#### What I'm Really Trying to Do

I want to make my own version of placeholders on top of the drag/drop api. I'm working on an app where the draggable items can take up most of the screen width, so we just want to show a line (in css just a border on whichever item as necessary, not an actual element) as a placeholder, that moves to the left side of an item if the user hovers over the left half and vice versa for the right. I'd like to use the dragenter/dragleave events to know when to apply the placeholder class to a certain item, because otherwise I pretty much have to calculate which item is being hovered based on the mouse position relative to the items in the drop list.

Issues.Title: Option to use dragStartDelay only for touch events
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Ability to control which events cause dragStartDelay to be used.

#### Use Case

`dragStartDelay` works great for touch screen devices to prevent dragging when you meant to scroll, but on the desktop with the mouse it just makes it feel like it's buggy or unresponsive. It'd be great if we had the ability to choose which events it applied to - even better if it defaulted to only applying to touch-screen events.
